Yes, the authorities at the Shrine have implemented several renewable energy sources to power the facilities, reducing their dependence on fossil fuels and decreasing their carbon footprint. The use of renewable energy sources is in line with the Saudi Vision 2030 initiative, which aims to increase the share of renewables in the country's energy mix.

One of the significant renewable energy sources used at the Shrine is solar energy. The desert region receives abundant sunlight throughout the year, and the authorities have utilized this resource to generate electricity. The solar panels placed on the rooftops of the buildings generate electricity, which is used to power the facilities and amenities in the Shrine.

In addition to solar energy, the authorities also use wind energy to generate electricity through wind turbines. The wind turbines are placed in strategic locations around the Shrine area to take advantage of the strong winds blowing in the region.

Besides, the authorities also use geothermal energy to power the facilities. Geothermal energy involves harnessing the energy produced by the Earth's crust, and it is used to provide cooling and heating to the buildings in the Shrine area.

The use of renewable energy sources at the Shrine is a significant step towards establishing sustainable and environmentally-friendly practices. It also serves as a model for other large-scale religious or tourist sites worldwide, encouraging them to adopt renewable energy practices to reduce their carbon footprint.
